Mistakeå˜…å¾Œæœä¿‚void ab initio
Misrepresentationå˜…å¾Œæœä¿‚voidable
Such a distinctive reason can be explained as follows:
For mistake, there is no meeting of minds of two parties either because of res extincta or res sua.
Some argue that res extincta can simply mean that the condition precedent upon the existence of a valid contract has ceased to exist before the signing of contract and hence the contract has never existed from the very beginning; whereas for res sua it is just a lack of valuable consideration such that the contract cannot come into existence without fulfilling the basic requirement of consideration. However you understand the concept of mistake, mistake simply means something fundamental to the formation of contract does not exist at the very beginning, such that the contract should not exist and should be void an initio.
For misrepresentation, it deals with the way in which consent was obtained is defective. Although both parties voluntarily enter into a contract with all the basic requirements fulfilled, the way in which the contract is formed is based on some misleading representation, such that the law gives the mere equity to the misrepresented to have the contract rescinded. Only when the mere equity can overcome all obstacles barring the rescission can a contract be validly rescinded. Voidable in other words simply means one cannot take the 'void an initio' legal consequence as granted, as it is always subject to the barring factors of rescission, i.e laches, restitution in integrum, right of equity's darling (a bona fide purchaser of legal interest for value without notice), etc.

æœ‰å†‡å·´æ‰“å¯ä»¥è¬›ä¸‹contract law é»è¬›é»æ¨£å…ˆå¯ä»¥æœ‰æ•ˆåœ°åˆ†åˆ°misrepresentationå®šmistake é™¤å·¦inducingåŒwrong assumptionä¹‹å¤–ä»²å¯ä»¥é»åˆ†


ç¨‹åº¦ä¸Šå””åŒ
Mistake åš´é‡å¥½å¤š as it's fundamental to the contract and will void it
Misrepresentation ä¿‚mere voidable
æœ‰éŒ¯å‹¿å±Œ

ææ¸…æ¥šå…ˆï¼š
Mistakeå˜…å¾Œæœä¿‚void ab initio
Misrepresentationå˜…å¾Œæœä¿‚voidable
Such a distinctive reason can be explained as follows:
For mistake, there is no meeting of minds of two parties either because of res extincta or res sua.
Some argue that res extincta can simply mean that the condition precedent upon the existence of a valid contract has ceased to exist before the signing of contract and hence the contract has never existed from the very beginning; whereas for res sua it is just a lack of valuable consideration such that the contract cannot come into existence without fulfilling the basic requirement of consideration. However you understand the concept of mistake, mistake simply means something fundamental to the formation of contract does not exist at the very beginning, such that the contract should not exist and should be void an initio.
For misrepresentation, it deals with the way in which consent was obtained is defective. Although both parties voluntarily enter into a contract with all the basic requirements fulfilled, the way in which the contract is formed is based on some misleading representation, such that the law gives the mere equity to the misrepresented to have the contract rescinded. Only when the mere equity can overcome all obstacles barring the rescission can a contract be validly rescinded. Voidable in other words simply means one cannot take the 'void an initio' legal consequence as granted, as it is always subject to the barring factors of rescission, i.e laches, restitution in integrum, right of equity's darling (a bona fide purchaser of legal interest for value without notice), etc.
